nodes.bodyText:
anyone able to check if this works on IE 11?

I suspect that it needs a manual fallback, looks like the postcss processor isn't adding the fallback for it

Seems to work on i.e but the entire dark theme doesn't
Here is a side by side with ie11 on the left and edge on the right

Seems to work on i.e but the entire dark theme doesn't

It's not expected to work on IE 11 at all for the theme

Here is a side by side with ie11 on the left and edge on the right

That's not working, at least for fonts, the preprocessor isn't picking them up 😢,
Two options I guess,

this work doesn't really require the fonts to be changeable at runtime, so it could go back to less variables
try out the other postcss plugin and see if that handles fonts, this one only seems to handle colours

cc @fqueiruga

Some more observations I made:

The administrative monitor (The bell thing in the top right) still shows white background on the dark theme
CLI page has black text with dark theme.
Thanks I’d forgotten about the admin monitor issue, and I hadn’t checked the CLI page
BTW I would not bother converting the arrow to a CSS variables. It should be either an icon or a CSS triangle, not an image anyway.
https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-62496
Maybe the fact that the variables are declared here and not in :root is causing the fallback issues. Just some brainstorming.
Yes you’re right
Maybe we should just go ahead and create a big & comprehensive variables.less file and be done with it :D
This is an adjunct, fallback should be done by hand.
I don't know if we should just override the :root variable here
hmm? not quite sure what you mean

Is this variable declared anywhere?
I wouldn't apply the styles to the setup wizard. Right know they are on their own and can behave weirdly if the variables are mixed.
I'm thinking that maybe we should just treat these links and the ones in the footer as a dark link variant. They all behave the same, and I don't think we should be hyper specific here.

they are used for different parts of the interface though, one is used for background colour and this is used for hover, bit wary of overloading variables, internally they are re-using the same colour variable, but they are different parts of the interface...
I didn't see this was about bg color nevermind. My comments were about color and font-weight basically.
Does this apply to all panes? For example, in a future PR I was going to change it just for side-panel widgets, dunno if this would affect it.
it's applied to .pane-header, .pane-footer
Does the plugin order matter? I'm thinking if there can be a scenario where the CSS variables fallback are applied for a main CSS rule but not for the vendor prefixes.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,7 @@
+module.exports = {
+  parser: "postcss-less",
+  plugins: [
+    require('autoprefixer'),
+    require('postcss-custom-properties')

nodes.bodyText: isn't the postcss-custom-properties applied second so it'll be applied on top of the prefixed?

nodes.bodyText: No idea, that's why I was asking.

nodes.bodyText: Why did you need to create this? Does this fix something?
it allows overriding the yui-skin in themes, I've matched the css below to what the yui skin provides and extended it with variables
I think this should be renamed to --border-radius
thanks, checked and you're right!
so reading up on what this does. Doesn't custom-properties plugin remove all the variables and replace them with the actual values?

   parser: "postcss-less",
   plugins: [
-    require('autoprefixer')
+    require('autoprefixer'),
+    require('postcss-custom-properties')

nodes.bodyText:
No it doesn’t remove them it adds the fallbacks above the variables for browsers that don’t support them (IE)
The theme wouldn’t work at all if it did it in the way you described

nodes.bodyText: shouldn't this fallback be kept?
Post css handles that
Defined but never used, also naming inconsistent with other variables.
Should be removed IMO
Is it deliberate that here and further below, we're not using a separate variable for the primary button border? Secondary buttons have a separate variable.
historical most likely, not intentional as far as I know
Button variable API should be expanded IMO
